titleStmt.title: Intermuscular adipose tissue accumulation is associated with higher tissue sodium in healthy individuals

sourceDesc.bibl: Lale A. Ertuglu, Melis Sahinoz, Aseel Alsouqi, Serpil Muge Deger, Andrew Guide, Mindy Pike, Cassianne Robinson‐Cohen, Elvis Akwo, Michael Pridmore, Rachelle Crescenzi, Meena S. Madhur, Annet Kirabo, David G. Harrison, Friedrich C. Luft, Jens Titze, T. Alp Ikizler, Jorge L. Gamboa. (2024). Intermuscular adipose tissue accumulation is associated with higher tissue sodium in healthy individuals. Physiological Reports, 12(13), None. DOI: 10.14814/phy2.16127

text.front:
C O N T R I B U T E D P A P E R
The varying effects of benefit types on community
members' views of whether they gain from wildlife
Stefan Carpenter
Department of Ecology and
Environmental Studies, Florida Gulf
Coast University, Fort Myers,
Florida, USA
Correspondence
Stefan Carpenter, Department of Ecology
and Environmental Studies, Florida Gulf
Coast University, 10501 FGCU Blvd. S.,
Fort Myers, FL 33965, USA.
Email: scarpenter@fgcu.edu
Funding information
Ostrom Workshop, Indiana University;
Wildize Foundation
Abstract
Community-based conservation (CBC) is a popular governance approach that
asks rural populations to sustainably manage local wildlife resources. CBC pro-
grams often rely on the distribution of wildlife benefits to communities to fos-
ter tolerance of wildlife, with the idea that those benefits can offset costs
arising from human-wildlife conflict. A survey of residents in four Namibian
CBC areas found that different benefit types varied significantly in their rela-
tionship with whether respondents felt that wildlife improved their lives. Some
higher monetary value benefits evidenced a negative and/or non-significant
relationship with respondents' perceptions, whereas meat-based benefits were
associated with a greater likelihood of residents feeling that they benefited
from wildlife. These findings suggest that the impact of different benefit types
in CBC programs may depend on a host of cultural/social, psychological, and
community-specific factors. From a practical standpoint, the form of direct
monetary benefits may matter, and cultural considerations likely play an
important role in determining which and when specific benefits are more
effective.
K E Y W O R D S
Africa, benefits, CBNRM, community-based conservation, conservancy, human-wildlife
conflict, Namibia, wildlife
text.body:
1 | INTRODUCTION
Community-based conservation (CBC) is a popular wildlife
governance approach 1 that has been adopted across the
global south, particularly in southern and eastern Africa
(Carpenter, 2021, 2022; Gruber, 2010; Roe et al., 2009). CBC
seeks to incentivize local communities to actively partici-
pate in wildlife conservation efforts by devolving to them
control over and the right to profit from wildlife resources
(Child & Barnes, 2010; Pienaar et al., 2013; Störmer
et al., 2019). As implemented, the approach generally relies
on the distribution of wildlife-generated benefits to increase
the tolerance of wildlife by rural populations (Scanlon &
Kull, 2009), hinging on the central tenet that people will
participate in the sustainable management of wildlife if the
perceived benefits associated with wildlife outweigh (or at
least equal) the perceived costs (Gosling et al., 2017;
Mogende & Kolawole, 2016; Thakadu, 2005).
At the level of the individual, costs associated with
wildlife management arise because of human-wildlife con-
flict (HWC), a term referring to monetary and
non-monetary harm experienced by people because of
text.front:

DOI: 10.1111/csp2.13217

the original work is properly cited.
© 2024 The Author(s). Conservation Science and Practice published by Wiley Periodicals LLC on behalf of Society for Conservation Biology.
Conservation Science and Practice. 2024;6:e13217.
wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/csp2
1 of 14
https://doi.org/10.1111/csp2.13217
text.body:
wildlife. HWC can manifest in multiple direct forms,
including livestock predation, crop-raiding and food stores
destruction, disease transmission to livestock and people,
and attacks on humans (Dickman, 2010; Meyer &
Börner, 2022). HWC can also include passive forms of con-
flict, such as limitations on economic opportunities or life-
style choice. Examples of this form of conflict can include
loss of grazing territory, foregone schooling or employment
opportunities because of the need to guard crops or live-
stock, or social stigmas associated with the loss of a family
member due to HWC (Barua et al., 2013; Carpenter, 2022).
The presence of HWC can significantly decrease the will-
ingness of individuals to tolerate (and, hence, sustainably
manage) "problem" wildlife (Pienaar et al., 2013).
CBC has realized mixed results in practice, and a
robust body of research explores both the governance
approach and the impact of benefits as a whole on the
opinions or attitudes of CBC participants toward conserva-
tion efforts (e.g., Cooney et al., 2018; Sampaio dos Reis &
Benchimol, 2023). CBC outcomes have been found to be
associated with a host of factors both internal and external
to participating communities, including the size and distri-
bution of conservation benefits (e.g., Calfucura, 2018;
Meyer et al., 2021; Waylen et al., 2010). A range of theoret-
ical frameworks, including but not limited to social
exchange theory, behavioral economics, environmental
criminology, social-ecological systems, and expectancy
models (e.g., theory of reasoned action and theory of
planned behavior), have also been applied to explain indi-
viduals' tolerance of wildlife and decision-making in the
presence of HWC (e.g., McCleery, 2009; Mogomotsi
et al., 2020; Ntuli et al., 2021; Sethi, 2022).
Limited field research suggests that a substantive dif-
ference may exist between direct and indirect (individual
or household-level vs. community-level) benefits, as well
as between monetary and non-monetary benefit types in
fostering greater tolerance of wildlife (e.g., Kansky &
Knight, 2014). However, CBC benefits can take myriad
forms (Ashley, 1998; Jani et al., 2022; Suich, 2013), and
few field studies have evaluated the individual effects of
each of those different benefit types on residents' atti-
tudes toward wildlife. This article addresses this gap in
our understanding by examining the perceptions of resi-
dents in four Namibian Conservancies (CBC areas). Spe-
cifically, I examine the relationship between the benefit
types received by residents and their perceptions regard-
ing the impact of wildlife on their lives.
2 | PREDICTIONS
I was unable to identify any previously tested, systematic
predictions regarding the respective impacts of different
benefit types. However, a small body of relevant field
research supports the generation of the following two
predictions:
Prediction 1: The receipt of any type of direct house-
hold benefit will increase the likelihood that a person
feels that wildlife improves his or her life.
Prediction 2: The receipt of direct monetary benefits,
such as wages or cash distributions, will have a greater
positive effect on recipients' opinions regarding the
impact of wildlife on their lives than will the receipt of
direct non-monetary benefits, such as meat distributions.
Field studies of CBC regimes find that widely distrib-
uted and higher-value benefits increase residents' support
for conservation efforts (Angula et al., 2018; MacKenzie
et al., 2017). Residents in CBC areas rarely directly
receive benefits, compared with indirect community-level
benefits such as schools or infrastructure improvements,
but even a limited distribution of direct benefits can be
significant as these areas often lack economic opportuni-
ties (Gosling et al., 2017). Households prioritize the
receipt of food, cash, and jobs from CBC programs, with
cash and employment being particularly desired (Naidoo,
Fisher, et al., 2016; Pienaar et al., 2014). Cash distribu-
tions can be especially important because they allow
households to purchase provisions and pay for school
fees (Pienaar et al., 2014; Scanlon & Kull, 2009).
Monetary benefits are linked to increased tolerance of
certain wildlife species and higher support for CBC
efforts (Kansky et al., 2020; Meyer & Börner, 2022). 2
However, while cash payments may demonstrate overall
efficacy, distributions in the form of predation compensa-
tion payments may not meaningfully counteract lowered
perceptions of CBC efforts caused by experience with
HWC (Meyer & Börner, 2022).
In comparison to cash, the impact of meat is less clear.
Suich (2013) found that meat benefits have little impact on
recipients' perceptions of wildlife because of the benefit's
relatively low economic value. On the other hand, Störmer
et al. (2019) found that both meat benefits and the pres-
ence of high levels of hunting benefits were associated
with positive attitudes toward wildlife, while Jones and
Weaver (2009) observed that recipients of direct benefits
such as meat and employment tend to have a more posi-
tive view of the impact of CBC on their lives.
It is important to note the limitations of the above
predictions. First, I rely only on existing field-based CBC
research that allows for differentiation of the impact of
different benefit types, rather than on broader literature
that discusses the role of undifferentiated benefits. Sec-
ond, I do not turn to literature outside of field-based CBC
studies, and I therefore do not make any predictions
based on socio-cultural factors or behavioral/
psychological frameworks discussed therein. 3 Rather, the
text.note:
CARPENTER
25784854, 2024, 9, Downloaded from https://conbio.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/csp2.13217 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
predictions stated above are narrowly designed to test
the applicability of findings from prior field studies to the
CBC jurisdictions included in this study. It is my hope
that the findings from this study will inform future,
broader investigations into the efficacy of different bene-
fit types.
3 | MATERIALS AND METHODS
3.1 | Site selection and development of
surveys
This study administered household-level surveys in four
conservancies (formally recognized CBC areas) in
Namibia's northwestern Kunene region (Figure 1). The
selected conservancies-from West to East, Puros, Ses-
fontein, Anabeb, and Omatendeka (collectively referred
to here as the "study area")-are of similar age and each
reported earning greater wildlife-generated income than
losses from HWC during the period of 2014-2017
(Namibian Association of CBNRM Support Organisations
[NACSO], 2017). The conservancies earn their income
through various combinations of phototourism, safari
hunting, and external governmental and non-
governmental support.
I met with traditional authorities and conservancy
representatives for each of the conservancies in May 2017
to administer semi-structured interviews of those individ-
uals and to obtain permission to administer the survey. I
pretested the survey instrument used in this study in the
Otjambangu Conservancy, which sits east of the Puros
Conservancy and north of the remaining three selected
conservancies. Additional information about the study
area and development of the survey can be found in the
Supporting Information.
F I G U R E 1 Map of Namibia's Conservancies with highlighted study area. Map adapted from conservation areas map A3. Source:
NACSO.
text.note: 25784854, 2024, 9, Downloaded from https://conbio.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/csp2.13217 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
3.2 | Survey administration
Household-level survey administration took place
between September and December 2017. Measurement at
the household-level is appropriate given that direct bene-
fits in these conservancies are often distributed at that
level.
The population in the study area was widely dis-
persed with a low population density, preventing the use
of probability sampling. To ensure that the respondents
to the survey reflected the composition of the overall
population as closely as possible, this study used non-
proportional quota sampling. Otherwise, the administra-
tors attempted, where possible, to randomize the pattern
by which households were selected for participation.
The participants were assured of anonymity, their
names were not recorded by the survey administrators,
and the research received both Institutional Review Board
approval and permission from Namibia's Ministry of Envi-
ronment and Tourism. Additional information regarding
participant sampling and survey design/administration
can be found in the Supporting Information.
3.3 | Selected survey questions
Respondents were asked the following questions regard-
ing both their perceptions of wildlife impact and the ben-
efits they received from the conservancy:
3.3.1 | Perceptions of wildlife impact
(outcome variable)
• Respond to the question: "Overall, has wildlife made
your own life better, worse, or about the same?"
3.3.2 | Benefits (explanatory variables of
interest)
• Identify if they or anyone in their household was
employed by their conservancy.
• Identify whether they had received any of the follow-
ing benefits from their conservancy:
1. Cash payments
2. Meat from animals killed by a trophy hunter
3. School scholarship or other educational expenses
4. Funeral assistance 4
5. Business loans
6. Use of infrastructure improvement (e.g., borehole
or conservancy vehicle)
7. Other
The question regarding participants' perception of
wildlife was purposefully undefined, and preceded more
specific questions regarding predation, monetary payouts,
meat distributions, and the like. Individuals can and do
include both tangible (e.g., meat or money) and intangi-
ble (e.g., symbolic or esthetic) considerations in their
evaluation of wildlife (ex., Jones & Weaver, 2009). The
positioning and wording of this question allowed respon-
dents to weigh any and all considerations in assessing
whether they gain from wildlife. The full survey is con-
tained in the Supporting Information, together with
demographic information regarding respondents.
3.4 | Alternate explanatory variables
Respondents were asked to provide information regard-
ing the following alternate explanatory variables, which
were included across various models as discussed below:
• Respondent's gender;
• Respondent's age;
• Household wealth (measured by number of livestock);
• Respondent's level of education;
• Household size;
• The conservancy in which the respondent resides; and
• Whether the household had suffered any loss of live-
stock or crops from predation within the prior
12 months.
Females are often found to be less likely to view wild-
life positively than are men (Dressel et al., 2015;
Kaltenborn et al., 1999; Kellert & Berry, 1987;
Sundaresan et al., 2012), although some studies have not
found any meaningful gender-based differences in per-
ceptions of wildlife (Dressel et al., 2015; Parry &
Campbell, 1992; Störmer et al., 2019) or have found that
women perceive wildlife more favorably (Barthwal &
Mathur, 2012; Dressel et al., 2015). Age is frequently neg-
atively associated with attitudes toward wildlife (Angula
et al., 2018; Bjerke et al., 1998; Dressel et al., 2015;
Kaltenborn et al., 1999). Increased education levels are
generally associated with more positive views of wildlife
(Barthwal & Mathur, 2012; Bjerke et al., 1998; Dressel
et al., 2015; but see Störmer et al., 2019).
Wealth has sometimes been identified as impacting
views of wildlife and wildlife conservation, although no
clear direction for that relationship exists, with prior
studies finding both that wealth is positively correlated
(Bandyopadhyay et al., 2009; Romañach et al., 2007) and
negatively correlated (Kanapaux & Child, 2011; Silva &
Mosimane, 2012) with attitudes toward wildlife. House-
hold size appears to be negatively associated with
text.note:
CARPENTER
25784854, 2024, 9, Downloaded from https://conbio.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/csp2.13217 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
attitudes toward wildlife and formal wildlife conservation
(Ochieng et al., 2021; Shrestha & Alavalapati, 2006).
Finally, past exposure to HWC is associated with the
development of negative attitudes toward wildlife and/or
specific wildlife species (Carter et al., 2014; Kansky
et al., 2016; Ochieng et al., 2021; Songorwa et al., 2000;
Spiteri & Nepalz, 2006).
3.5 | Method of analysis
I employed a two-stage exact logistic regression (ELR)
(Carpenter, 2021), in which the first stage examined the
probability that a respondent would select a response
coded higher than "À1" for the outcome variable
(i.e., that she feels wildlife made her life about the same
or better), and the second stage explored the probability
that a respondent would select a response of "1"
(i.e., wildlife made her life better). This two-stage analysis
mirrors the approach used in generalized ordered logit
models (GOLMs) (a.k.a., proportional odds models), in
that both methods of analysis utilize a series of cumula-
tive logistic regressions, avoiding the "parallel lines"
assumption, employed by ordinal logit models, that all
coefficients except for intercepts are the same across mul-
tiple regressions (Williams, 2016). This assumption is
often problematic when respondents assess their own
well-being, as it would assume that the effect of a vari-
able would necessarily have the same impact on an indi-
vidual choosing a neutral response (e.g., selecting that
they are "OK" over "bad") as it would on an individual
choosing a positive response (e.g., selecting that they are
"great" over "OK") (Cracolici et al., 2013; Harzing, 2016).
The difference between the two-stage ELR used here
and the GOLM approach is that the latter relies on a
maximum likelihood approach, the assumptions of which
are inappropriate for two conditions that occur within
my data: (1) smaller data sets and (2) some variable com-
binations (i.e., cell counts) having few or no observations
(Faghih et al., 2020; Gao & Shen, 2007; King &
Ryan, 2002; Mehta & Patel, 1995; Quintero et al., 2007).
ELRs produce more accurate inferences under these con-
ditions because the approach does not use maximum
likelihood; rather, the estimate of each variable is sepa-
rately calculated while conditioning out all the other
explanatory variables (Giannakis & Bruggeman, 2015).
ELR is computationally intensive, making it infeasi-
ble to include multiple explanatory variables for anything
other than the smallest datasets (Quintero et al., 2007).
Therefore, to allow for the inclusion of potentially impor-
tant explanatory benefits, I generated 148 different ELR
models representing all combinations of potential explan-
atory variables (each of the six direct variables
individually, and variable pairs of each of the direct vari-
ables regressed with each other and 16 alternate explana-
tory variables 5 ). 6
3.5.1 | Addressing "missing" data
The various benefit categories received differing response
rates. To ensure that the findings of the study were not
unduly influenced by different levels of nonresponses, I
generated predicted responses and reran the paired
regressions discussed above. The findings from the pre-
dicted dataset were consistent with the findings
presented here. I therefore do not further discuss the
findings from the predicted dataset. Results and addi-
tional information regarding predicted responses are in
the Supporting Information.
4 | RESULTS
Two hundred and seventy-two people fully or substan-
tially completed the survey, although the number of
responses varied for each of the questions asked. Approx-
imately 42% of respondents answered that wildlife made
their lives better, 39% stated that wildlife made their lives
worse, and the remainder replied that their lives were
about the same (Table 1).
Respondents most frequently reported receiving one
or more of the following six direct benefit types: meat
(84.16%), funeral assistance (68.34%), cash benefits
(16.42%), conservancy employment (14.07%), tuition
assistance (13.66%), and business loans (7.77%) (the cash,
tuition, business loans, and employment benefits are col-
lectively referred to here as "rare benefits"). Approxi-
mately 28% of respondents identified receiving indirect
benefits in the form of infrastructure, such as access to
community vehicles or boreholes.
The "other" category of benefits received noticeably
fewer responses than did the rest of the benefit categories,
but of those individuals that answered this sub-question,
around 10% received some additional benefit. Written
comments on the surveys indicate that respondents
included in this category both direct benefits (e.g., seeds
for planting, construction materials, and food to individ-
uals in need) and indirect benefits (e.g., a community
school and funding for conservancy-based soccer teams).
Thus, for the purposes of this analysis, this category is
included in the model as an indirect category of benefits.
None of the direct or indirect benefits are highly cor-
related. However, some of the rare benefits do evidence
moderately positive correlation with each other
(Table 2). 7
text.note: 25784854, 2024, 9, Downloaded from https://conbio.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/csp2.13217 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
4.1 | Analyses without alternative
explanatory variables
When no alternate explanatory variables were included, the
total number of benefit types received was positively and
significantly correlated with the likelihood that respondents
selected a more positive response about the impact of wild-
life on their lives (Table 3). 8 For each additional benefit type
received, respondents were approximately 23% more likely
to feel that wildlife at least had a neutral impact on their
lives (i.e., select either the "about the same" or "better"
choice) and 65% more likely to feel that wildlife made their
lives better. 9 However, the individual benefit types varied
widely in the direction, magnitude, and significance of their
respective relationship with respondents' perceptions.
When each of the benefits were individually regressed
with the outcome measure, the employment, funeral,
and meat benefits all had significant, positive associations
with the respondents' perceptions. By contrast, the
remaining benefits all evidenced negative and/or statisti-
cally insignificant relationships with respondents' percep-
tions of wildlife impact.
4.2 | Analyses including alternative
explanatory variables
When I included additional explanatory variables into my
models, my findings largely paralleled those found in
Table 3, discussed above. Averaged across all 148 models,
cash, tuition, infrastructure, and "other" benefits contin-
ued to have no statistically significant relationship with
respondents' opinions about the impact of wildlife on their
lives (Table 4). Further, the mean significance, magnitude,
and direction of the association of each of the employ-
ment, funeral, meat, and loan benefits were similar to
those found in the individual regressions presented above.
5 | DISCUSSION
The data fails to support Prediction 1 (the receipt of any
type of benefit will be positively associated with the like-
lihood that residents will feel that wildlife improves their
lives). Overall, the number of benefits a household
receives has a significant and positive correlation with

text.note: 25784854, 2024, 9, Downloaded from https://conbio.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/csp2.13217 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
the likelihood that a resident feels that wildlife makes
her life better. However, the findings in this study suggest
that different benefit types may vary greatly in their indi-
vidual influence on residents' perceptions, with some
individual benefit types even potentially undermining
recipients' attitudes toward wildlife.
The data also fails to support Prediction 2 (direct
monetary benefits in the form of wages or cash distribu-
tions will have a greater positive impact than direct non-
monetary benefits), but these findings warrant additional
discussion, as it appears that the form of the payment
may matter. The receipt of cash or tuition payments evi-
denced no statistically significant relationship with peo-
ple's opinions of the impact of wildlife on their lives,
while those who received business loans were signifi-
cantly less likely to feel that wildlife at least had a neutral
impact. But, by contrast, respondents in households
receiving conservancy wages were over three times more
likely to feel that wildlife made their lives better, and
recipients of funeral benefits (which include both meat
and money) were over two times more likely to perceive
both that wildlife had a neutral and positive impact on
their lives. Interestingly, my findings suggest that the
receipt of trophy meat may have had the greatest and
most consistent impact on participants' views of wildlife.
Across all variable pairs, recipients of meat benefits were
approximately three times and four times more likely to
feel that wildlife had either a neutral or beneficial effect,
respectively, on their lives.
The large, positive association of the funeral and
employment benefits is perhaps unsurprising. Pre-survey
interviewees stated that funeral benefits provide both
meat and cash benefits. As such, they likely represent a
social service that can be directly attributed to wildlife-
both via the game meat provided and the payment of
money by the conservancy, which exists to collect and
manage wildlife-generated income. Absent these funeral
benefits, the families of the deceased would presumably
have to rely exclusively on their own resources to feed
funeral guests and cover any associated funeral costs.
Thus, funeral assistance likely represents significant eco-
nomic value-the gift of which is strongly linked to
wildlife-at a time when the household may be most in
need of financial, logistical, and emotional support.
Regarding the employment benefit, jobs in many CBC
areas are scarce and any form of employment is highly
coveted (Gosling et al., 2017; Naidoo, Fisher, et al., 2016).
Thus, individuals who have secured conservancy employ-
ment are highly likely to feel like their lives have signifi-
cantly improved. Since the employment is through the
conservancy, which was created for the purpose of govern-
ing wildlife, those individuals are also likely to attribute
the employment to the existence of wildlife.
The negative or non-significant association of some
cash benefits in this study, on the other hand, is unex-
pected, although not entirely unprecedented. For
instance, the percentage of direct household wildlife ben-
efits in Botswana was not correlated with positive atti-
tudes toward wildlife (Parry & Campbell, 1992). The
receipt of either cash or employment benefits in
Namibia's Zambezi region was not associated with any
sizeable or significant change in participants' support for
their conservancy (Muyengwa, 2015). 10 Finally, individ-
uals in Indonesia directly benefiting from tourism to a
nearby national park voiced lower than expected support
for conservation of the park (Walpole & Goodwin, 2002).
Still, each of the business loans, tuition, and cash bene-
fits has tangible monetary value, and the bulk of the field
literature discussed in the predictions section suggests that
they should therefore be expected to have a significant,
positive correlation with recipients' views of wildlife. My
available data do not allow me to conclusively explain my
finding that some form of cash-based benefits may be
more effective than others. However, I present three possi-
ble explanations for this finding. 11
First, participants' perceptions may be the result of a
psychological phenomenon. It is generally observed that
individuals evaluate their well-being by comparing their
current circumstance to a subjectively derived standard
(McBride, 2010; Medvec et al., 1995). 12 Individuals that
perceive themselves better off than that benchmark are
more likely to be satisfied with their current situation,
while those perceiving themselves worse off are more
likely to feel dissatisfied (Castilla, 2012; Hafner
et al., 2016; McBride, 2010; Villano et al., 2020).
Individuals' benchmarks can be based on factors such
as the individuals' past experiences, the perceived circum-
stances of peers, or hypothetical scenarios (Castilla, 2012;
Epstude & Roese, 2008; Hafner et al., 2016;
McBride, 2010; Roese & Morrison, 2009). The use of these
psychological benchmarks appears to be universal, hav-
ing been observed across different countries and cultures
(Arkes et al., 2010; Epstude & Roese, 2008; Gilovich
et al., 2016; Hafner et al., 2016). Individuals adjust these
standards over time in response to changes in circum-
stances and personal experiences (Arkes et al., 2010;
Bertoni & Corazzini, 2015; Chao et al., 2017;
McBride, 2010; Mentzakis & Moro, 2009; Van Hoeck
et al., 2015).
In this study, the lack of significance of several forms
of cash-based benefits may be the result of recipients feel-
ing that the benefits they received fell short of their own
subjective benchmarks. This feeling might arise in two
circumstances.
Benefit recipients may have experienced "expectation
creep" where, in response to the past receipt of a cash
text.note:
CARPENTER
25784854, 2024, 9, Downloaded from https://conbio.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/csp2.13217 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
benefit, they adjusted their economic benchmarks
upwards and were consequently disappointed by the lack
or size of subsequent payments. Welch (2018) observed
expectation creep of this sort in Namibia's N#a-Jaqna
Conservancy, where a false rumor of additional benefit
payments caused residents to be dissatisfied with their
(usually well received) benefits. In my pre-survey inter-
views, multiple individuals indicated that cash benefits
had not been made in many years, and one traditional
authority specifically told me that the needs and expecta-
tions of residents had grown over that time. Thus, a simi-
lar sort of expectation creep might have been experienced
by participants in my study who had previously received
now discontinued cash benefits.
Cash recipients could also feel dissatisfied if they were
well-connected individuals who anticipated an even
greater payout from their conservancies. Elite capture is
an issue frequently observed in CBC communities
(Groom & Harris, 2008; Lubilo & Hebinck, 2019;
MacKenzie et al., 2017; Morton et al., 2016; Naidoo,
Weaver, et al., 2016) and my data suggest that it may be
occurring in my project's study area. Roughly half
(49.98%) of the recipients of one rare benefit in my
response group received at least one additional rare bene-
fit, as opposed to the 12.46% of recipients that should be
expected to have received two rare benefits if distribution
was truly random. In their survey responses, most
respondents indicated that they believed that favoritism
was occurring within the conservancies, as did some par-
ticipants in pre-survey interviews (Cruise and Sasada
(2021) reported similar complaints of favoritism). To the
extent that elite capture is occurring in the study area, it
could be that well-connected individuals may have antici-
pated receiving a much greater magnitude of benefits and
were disappointed when they received smaller-
than-expected payments.
A second possible explanation for this study's findings
(that meat benefits had a positive relationship with per-
ceptions of wildlife while most of the monetary benefits
did not) is that meat may have particular socio-cultural
resonance with recipients. Multiple studies across sub-
Saharan Africa observe that meat has both symbolic and
dietary significance. Meat is considered by many to be an
integral part of a meal (Erasmus & Hoffman, 2017), and
its consumption is associated with celebration, wealth,
and hospitality (Asamane et al., 2021). Livestock are con-
sidered monetary assets and important symbols of
wealth, so consumption of those animals can be reserved
for special occasions or to feed important visitors
(Bundala et al., 2020). Hunting has traditionally occurred
in the study area, especially as a supplemental food
source during times of scarcity (Jacobsohn, 1995; Morais
et al., 2015). Wildlife meat is also valued by inhabitants
of the study area for its taste (depending on the species)
and because of the perception that it is healthier due to
being free of harmful chemicals (Crandall, 2002; Morais
et al., 2015).
Thus, distributions of game meat may represent a
meaningful form of wealth distribution to recipients, and
the provision of that meat at funerals could have impor-
tant social significance, while also mitigating the need for
the family to utilize its own livestock resources. Regular
meat distributions may therefore be perceived by recipi-
ents in my study as imbuing greater total wealth than the
occasional monetary payment.
A third possible explanation of this study's findings is
that employment, trophy meat, and funeral benefits may
have a more obvious link to wildlife than the cash, loans,
and tuition benefits. Meat distributions come from wild-
life hunted within the conservancies, and employment
directly involves the governance of the conservancies'
wildlife resources, including occupations such as game
guards or lion spotters.
By contrast, the direct link with wildlife is less obvi-
ous for tuition, business loans, and cash benefits. While
the benefits are distributed through the conservancy, it
may be unclear to many recipients whether the money
for those payments was derived directly from wildlife or
from other outside sources of funding (e.g. from govern-
mental or non-governmental sources). As such, it may be
that recipients of non-employment cash benefits are less
likely to associate the positive impacts of those benefits
with wildlife and are consequently less likely to feel that
wildlife has a positive impact on their lives.
6 | CONCLUSIONS
At minimum, my findings indicate that perceptions sur-
rounding wildlife-generated benefits are complex. Partici-
pants may attribute greater or lesser importance to
particular benefit types than is traditionally assumed in
the design of payment-based conservation programs,
where it is taken for granted that monetary payouts will
have the greatest possible impact. The impact of mone-
tary and non-monetary benefits on community support
for wildlife conservation likely depends on a host of dif-
ferent factors, including but not limited to the frequency
and timing of benefit distributions, relevant social factors,
and how easily the benefits are linked to wildlife.
The findings presented here give rise to two key prac-
tical recommendations. First, the form of direct monetary
benefits likely matters. Meyer and Börner (2022) previ-
ously found that monetary distributions in the form of
compensation payments may not materially change
recipients' perceptions of CBC among those that have
text.note: 25784854, 2024, 9, Downloaded from https://conbio.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/csp2.13217 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.body:
experienced HWC. My findings suggest that other forms
of monetary payments may also be highly variable, or
even counterproductive, at positively influencing recipi-
ent perceptions. Policymakers should carefully consider
and evaluate the effectiveness of the specific forms of
monetary benefits distributed within CBC communities.
Second, cultural considerations likely play an impor-
tant role in determining which and when benefits are more
effective. In the study area for this paper, meat benefits are
significantly and positively correlated with recipients' per-
ceptions of whether they benefit from wildlife. It is proba-
bly no coincidence that residents in that area have been
found to have a positive view of bushmeat consumption.
However, other studies have found that bushmeat con-
sumption can be highly variable based on tribe, nationality,
and religion (e.g., Ceppi & Nielsen, 2014; East et al., 2005).
Therefore, while meat benefits appear to be highly effective
in my study area, their efficacy elsewhere may depend on
the socio-cultural makeup of the target community.
Further research is warranted into how, why, and the
degree to which benefit types may relate to CBC resi-
dents' perceptions of whether they benefit from wildlife,
so that benefit design and distribution can be tailored to
specific CBC projects. For instance, understanding the
role of benefit frequency on efficacy could inform the
form and timing of benefit distributions. Research into
how, if at all, recipients use psychological benchmarks to
evaluate their benefits could influence communication
regarding benefit distributions and facilitate the active
management of community expectations.
text.div:
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
The Wildize Foundation and Indiana University's Ostrom
Workshop funded this study.

CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT
The author has no financial or non-financial interests to
disclose.

DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
Low population levels in the study area mean that survey
and interview responses could potentially be attributed to
individuals through the process of elimination. For this
reason, the data used in this paper are not being made
publicly available. Individuals wishing to access the data
are invited to contact the author.

ETHICS STATEMENT
The research received both Institutional Review Board
approval and permission from Namibia's Ministry of
Environment and Tourism, and the procedures used in
this study adhere to the tenets of the Declaration of
Helsinki.
CONSENT TO PARTICIPATE
Informed consent was obtained from all individual par-
ticipants included in the study.

ENDNOTES
1 CBC can also be used to refer to the community-based manage-
ment of other natural resources, such as water, fish, or forests.
For purposes of simplicity, in this paper the term refers only to
wildlife-based CBC programs.
2 Meyer and Börner (2022) found that "additional benefits" (other
than compensation payments) were positively associated with
conservation efforts. The authors, however, included both cash
and unspecified "in-kind" payments in this category.
3 I do, however, turn to some of this literature when introducing
potential explanations for my findings.
4 Funeral assistance generally consists of game meat along with an
additional small cash payment to help defray funeral costs.
5 Computational limitations required that I create individual
models for each of four ethnicity and five conservancy selections.
Further explanation of these models can be found in the Support-
ing Information.
6 The use of multiple individual models gives rise to concerns
about a multiple hypothesis problem. Unfortunately, the same
limitation (smaller data set) that requires me to use exact logistic
regression also constrains my ability to correct for multiple
hypothesis. Existing approaches protect against Type I errors
(false positives) at the expense of statistical power and an
increased likelihood of Type II errors (false negatives)
(Nakagawa, 2004). Given the number of models used here, multi-
ple hypothesis testing would render it virtually impossible to find
any significant relationships at all. In effect, I would be selecting
a virtual certainty of at least one Type II error over the unknown
likelihood of a Type I error, and my findings would actually be
more likely to be biased.
As an admittedly imperfect substitute for correcting for multiple
hypotheses, I instead analyzed the data using traditional ordinal
logit models, one for each of the benefit types individually and
one that included all the benefit types and alternate explanatory
variables. The direction and, for the most part, the significance of
the relationships between the benefit types and the outcome vari-
able were the same for both approaches, although the two
approaches differed regarding the magnitude of the observed
relationships. A comparison of the results using the traditional
ordinal logit models with those presented herein can be found in
the Supporting Information.
7 Fitz-Gibbon and Morris (1987) suggest describing correlation
coefficients from 0.0 to 0.2 as "probably no correlation," from 0.2
to 0.4 as "weak correlation," and 0.4-0.6 as "moderately positive
correlation."
8 Table 3 (as does Table 4, below) reflects the likelihood that
respondents will select a higher level than the current one. Thus,
for instance, an odds ratio value greater than "1" for level À1
text.note:
CARPENTER
25784854, 2024, 9, Downloaded from https://conbio.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/csp2.13217 by Cochrane Portugal, Wiley Online Library on [10/09/2025]. See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License
text.div:
(wildlife makes my life worse) indicates an increased likelihood
that a respondent will select either 0 (about the same) or 1 (makes
my life better). That same odds ratio value for level 0 (about the
same) indicates an increased likelihood that a respondent would
select 1 (wildlife makes my life better).
9 The odds ratio refers to the likelihood of a unit change in an out-
come measure for every unit change in the variable of interest.
Here, the odds ratio refers to the likelihood of a unit increase
(from À1 to 0 or from 0 to 1) in whether respondents feel that
wildlife makes their lives better given a unit change in a benefits
variable. It should be noted that the percent change refers to the
percent by which the baseline odds change, not the magnitude of
that change.
10 Muyengwa's survey asked about support for conservancies,
rather than perceptions of wildlife. Consequently, the responses
in that study may be shaped by non-wildlife-related factors such
as corruption, conservancy responsiveness (or lack thereof) to
constituent concerns, or perceived favoritism in conservancy gov-
ernance. Still, Namibia's conservancies are designed to allow resi-
dents to utilize and benefit from their wildlife resources, so it is
likely that participants' views of their conservancies are related,
at least in part, to whether they feel they personally benefit from
wildlife.
11 As discussed in the Predictions section, the findings in Meyer and
Börner (2022) suggest that monetary compensation payments may
materially differ in their impact from other "in-kind" cash pay-
ments (although that article combines both cash and other unspe-
cified in-kind benefits). Unfortunately, I conducted this survey
prior to the publication of that article, so my data does not differ-
entiate whether recipients of cash payments received them in the
form of compensation and/or as some other form of payment. A
review of the raw data from my survey, however, does not identify
any facially clear pattern involving whether individuals applied
for compensation and/or received cash and their opinions as to
whether wildlife makes their lives better. Therefore, while this dis-
tinction may be important and certainly warrants future investiga-
tion, I do not further discuss it here.
12 These standards are often referred to as "counterfactuals" in the
psychological literature (Epstude & Roese, 2008; Roese &
Morrison, 2009) and "reference points" in economic writings
(Castilla, 2012; McBride, 2010).
